lines.text: Enter CLOTEN and two Lords

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: Was there ever man had such luck! when I kissed the jack, upon an up-cast to be hit away! I had a hundred pound on't: and then a whoreson jackanapes must take me up for swearing; as if I borrowed mine oaths of him and might not spend them at my pleasure.

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: What got he by that? You have broke his pate with your bowl.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: [Aside]  If his wit had been like him that broke it, it would have run all out.

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: When a gentleman is disposed to swear, it is not for any standers-by to curtail his oaths, ha?

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: No my lord; nor crop the ears of them.
Aside

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: Whoreson dog! I give him satisfaction? Would he had been one of my rank!

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: [Aside]  To have smelt like a fool.

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: I am not vexed more at any thing in the earth: a pox on't! I had rather not be so noble as I am; they dare not fight with me, because of the queen my mother: every Jack-slave hath his bellyful of fighting, and I must go up and down like a cock that nobody can match.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: [Aside]  You are cock and capon too; and you crow, cock, with your comb on.

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: Sayest thou?

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: It is not fit your lordship should undertake every companion that you give offence to.

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: No, I know that: but it is fit I should commit offence to my inferiors.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Ay, it is fit for your lordship only.

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: Why, so I say.

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: Did you hear of a stranger that's come to court to-night?

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: A stranger, and I not know on't!

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: [Aside]  He's a strange fellow himself, and knows it not.

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: There's an Italian come; and, 'tis thought, one of Leonatus' friends.

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: Leonatus! a banished rascal; and he's another, whatsoever he be. Who told you of this stranger?

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: One of your lordship's pages.

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: Is it fit I went to look upon him? is there no derogation in't?

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: You cannot derogate, my lord.

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: Not easily, I think.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: [Aside]  You are a fool granted; therefore your issues, being foolish, do not derogate.

lines.speaker: cloten
lines.text: Come, I'll go see this Italian: what I have lost to-day at bowls I'll win to-night of him. Come, go.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: I'll attend your lordship. That such a crafty devil as is his mother Should yield the world this ass! a woman that Bears all down with her brain; and this her son Cannot take two from twenty, for his heart, And leave eighteen. Alas, poor princess, Thou divine Imogen, what thou endurest, Betwixt a father by thy step-dame govern'd, A mother hourly coining plots, a wooer More hateful than the foul expulsion is Of thy dear husband, than that horrid act Of the divorce he'ld make! The heavens hold firm The walls of thy dear honour, keep unshaked That temple, thy fair mind, that thou mayst stand, To enjoy thy banish'd lord and this great land! a trunk in one corner of it. IMOGEN in bed, reading; a Lady attending
Exeunt CLOTEN and First Lord
Exit
